tmpls.name: IO Card

fields: What are examples of Lower tract infections?

Bronchitis, pneumonia
The other ones are in the upper respiratory tract.
Lower respiratory tract infections are {{c1::more::more/less}} severe.

Corynebacterium (diphtheria) is gram {{c1::positive}}
type of aerobe/anaerobe:{{c1::facultative anaerobe}}
contains {{c1::metachromatic}} granules

Corynebacterium diptheriae infects {{c1::superficial}} tissue. 
Local infection usually of the {{c1::throat}}, but also the {{c2::skin}}.
The {{c1::toxin}} of the Corynebacterium diptheriae is responsible for the manifestation of the disease.
The Corynebacterium diptheriae toxin inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells by inactivating {{c1::EF2}} (which inhibits translation), causing tissue destruction.

H.influenzae type b (Hib) 
Gram {{c1::negative rod}}
{{c1::non-::non/very}}motile
{{c2::Polyribophiosphate}} capsule (Hib vaccine against capsule)
Fastidious - only grows on {{c1::chocolate}} agar. 
Factor X ({{c3::protoporphryin I9 - hemin}}
Factor V [{{c3::NAD+}}]
The H.influenzae vaccine works against the {{c1::Hib capsule}}
Streptococcus pneumoniae is among the leading causes of {{c1::death}} throughout the world.
Streptococcus pneumoniae is the etiological organicim in {{c1::typical lobular pneumonia}}, {{c2::otitis media}}, {{c3::meningitis}}, and {{c4::bacteremia}}.

Streptococcus pneumoniae
role of the capsule- {{c1::virulence}} is directly dependent on the polysaccharide capsule (antiphagocytic)
Streptococcus pneumoniae releases {{c1::hemolysin}} that damages {{c2::respiratory}} epithelium.
Streptococcus pneumoniae: Alveoli exudes fluid, {{c1::RBCs}} and {{c1::WBCs}} leading to productive cough
Streptococcus pneumoniae can disseminate to {{c1::lymphatics}}, {{c1::blood}}, and other tissues.

Streptococcus pneumoniae 
Resistance is known to occur for penicillin
-this occurs by alteration of one or more of the bacteriums {{c1::penicillin binding proteins}}.
{{c2::Bordetella pertussis}} is also known as {{c1::whooping cough}}
Bordetella pertussis cite of infection is at the {{c1::nasopharynx}}, {{c2::ciliated cells of bronchi and trachea}}

Bordetella pertussis 
Symptoms and signs
Similar to {{c1::common cold}} at first

Then prolonged {{c2::characteristic}} cough

{{c3::Inflammation of respiratory}} tract

Bordetella pertussis
pathogenesis
affects children under {{c1::2}} years old
organism binds to {{c1::ciliated cells in the URT}}
toxin released and spread to ciliated cells of the {{c2::trachea and bronchi. }}

Bordetella pertussis
Pathogenesis
The toxin inhibits {{c1::DNA synthesis}} in epithelial cells

Bordetella pertussis
Pathogenesis
The toxin inhibits {{c1::phagocytes}} and thus {{c2::paralyses the immune system}}
Legionella pneumophilia is also known as a{{c1::typical pneumonia}}

Legionella pneumophilia 
General Characteristics
aquatic intracellular organism - lives in {{c1::amoeba::single-celled organism}}.

Legionella pneumophilia 
General Characteristics
transmission- {{c1::by water in fine mist}}.

Legionella pneumophilia 
General Characteristics
Contamination
{{c1::
- Central AC
-Hot water heaters
- water coolers
- spas
- showers. 
}}

Legionella pneumophilia 
General Characteristics
pathogenesis
- taken into {{c1::alveolar macrophages::what type of cell}}.

Legionella pneumophilia 
General Characteristics
pathogenesis
- inhibits {{c1::lysosome-phagosome fusion}} ({{c2::grows in phagosome}})

{{c2::Legionella pneumophilia }}
General Characteristics
pathogenesis
- secretes {{c1::proteases}} which destroy cellular proteins.

Legionella pneumophilia
causes legionnaire's disease
other side effects include - 
{{c1::
atypical pneumonia
myalgia
headache
fever
diarrhea
generally non productive cough. 
}}

Legionella pneumophilia
Treatment
{{c1::Antibiotics strong enough to penetrate human cells}}. 
{{c2::Levofloxacin and azithromycin}}.

Legionella pneumophilia
Prevention
{{c1::hyper-chlorinate water}}
{{c2::heat water to >70C to decomtaminate water source.}}

{{c3::Chlamydia psittaci }}
mode of transmission
{{c1::inhalation of dust}} containing {{c2::dried bird feces}} harboring organism.

{{c1::Chlamydia psittaci }}
Clinical picture
from {{c2::inapperent to infection and severe chills}}. 
resembles {{c1::influenza}}

{{c1::Chlamydia psittaci }}
Treatment and prevention
{{c2::doxycycline/azithromycin}}
{{c3::no vaccine::what type of vaccine?}}, quarantine of birds and livestock.

mycoplasma
general characteristics
{{c1::lack rigid cell wall::cell wall or not?}}
small
{{c2::pleomorphic::shape}}
require {{c2::cholesterol}} for growth
not affected by {{c1::penecillin}}
inhibited by {{c1::tetracycline}}

mycoplasma pneumoniae
incubation period {{c1::1-3 weeks}}
transmission {{c2::respiratory droplets. }}
mechanism of transport - adheres to {{c1::ciliated respiratory mucosal cells. }}
treatment - {{c2::tetracycline}}

mycoplasma pneumoniae
secretes {{c1::H202 and exotoxin}}
destroys {{c2::cilia and ciliated cells. }}

{{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}
found in the {{c2::respiratory and GI tract}}

{{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}
cause {{c2::disease primarily in patients with underlying disease or alcoholism}}

{{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}
can cause {{c2::UTI in patients with urinary catheters}}
{{c3::drug resistance}} is quite common.

{{c2::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}
produces {{c1::thick biofilm}}
enhances the organisms ability to colonize and adhere to surfaces. 
{{c1::capsule}} prevents phagocytosis.

mycobacteria are the cause of two of the most alarming diseases
{{c1::
Tuberculosis
leprosy
}}

Mycobacterium tuberculosis
{{c1::motile::motile/non-motile}}
{{c2::obligate aerobes::anaerobe/aerobe (what type)}}, 
{{c3::clustered::clustered, or not}} 
Don't form {{c4::spores}}
cell wall: {{c2::weakly gram positive}}
acid-fast bacilli

Mycobacterium tuberculosis
{{c1::Lipids + Polysaccharides + Peptides}} creates a {{c2::waxy}} cell surface that is highly hydrophobic and accounts for their acid fast staining characteristic

{{c3::Mycobacterium tuberculosis}}
Viable for weeks in {{c1::sputum, bedding}}, etc. {{c2::due to clumped growth}}

Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Can be killed by {{c1::heat, pasteurization, and sunlight}}
Once acid-fast bacilli are stained, they {{c1::cannot::can/can't}} be easily decolorized by treatment with acidified solvents.

Isolation of M. tuberculosis from relevant clinical material

Must isolate the {{c1::tubercle bacilli}} as proof of infection
Grow on {{c2::Lowenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook}} media
Organism produces {{c3::niacin}} (Most other mycobacterium do not)

Treatment of m tuberculosis includes
{{c1::isoniazid}}
{{c2::rifampin}}
{{c3::pyrazinamide}}
{{c4::thambutol}}
{{c5::streptomycin}}

I'm really positive that sucks.

Treatment of m. tuberculosis includes
multi-drug resistance is increasing
often used regimen
{{c1::
isoniazid
rifampin
pyrazinamide
}}  - I'm really proteinaceous. 
clinical cure in >95%

M. tuberculosis
prevention
{{c1::Prophylactic isoniazid}} for high risk groups

M. tuberculosis
prevention
{{c1::Prophylactic isoniazid}} for high risk groups
{{c2::Recent PPD converter (negative to positive)}}
{{c3::Young children in family of recent converter}}
{{c4::PPD+ patient on immunosuppressive drugs for another illness}}

M. tuberculosis
prevention
{{c1::BCG}} vaccine 
-not routinely used in the USA

M. tuberculosis
epidemiology
physiological factors
- those susceptible: {{c1::malnourished, stressed, overcrowding, coexisting diseases}}
- age factors {{c2::(infants, elderly)}}

very similar to m. tuberculosis
Prevalent in SE Asia, but also in Africa

M. leprae 
There is no growth on {{c1::artificial}} media
It's difficult to grow on lab animals, except for {{c2::mouse footpad and in the armadillo}}

M. leprae 
transmission
{{c1::Prolonged, close contact}} with someone with
untreated leprosy over many {{c2::months::weeks/months}} is needed

M. leprae 
affects {{c1::Cooler::cooler/hotter}} body parts (SKIN, NERVES)
{{c2::
Nose, outer, ears, testicles
Superficial nerve endings
}}

M. leprae 
is slow and leads to {{c1::peripheral neuritis}}
fatality is due to secondary infections e.g. M. tuberculosis

M. leprae 
diagnosis
{{c1::acid-fast staining::type of stain}}
histology of biopsy material

m. Bovis
Causes TB in cattle
Crosses species and cause disease in {{c3::humans and other animals. }}
{{c2::Highly virulent}}
affects {{c1::lymphatic system and bones}}.

atypical mycobacteria
are opportunists (M. avium-intracellulare) that are TB-like diseases associated with {{c1::AIDS}}.
Tend to be highly resistant to anti-TB drugs
